There have been a number of requests over the years:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=453385
creator: sfhowes

content:
It doesn't look like any devs have responded in a useful way to this request?

Original request for a raw body filter goes back 10-16 years!!! 453385&1211128

Most evilspammers and even a lot of goodspammers don't provide useful filtering sequences in the mail header, and the text part of the body is similarly useless.

The only useful patterns for capturing these are in the HTML section - which the Body filter ignores.

It looks like a RFE(request for enhancement) has already been made or mentioned - but no bites by the devs(?)

Message filtering is (guess) 80% dead in the water if you can't pick out a URL in any of the parts of the body, and block on it. It's gotten more and more this way over the last 10 years.

Do I need to buy one of the devs a case of beer to get this RFE acted on?

Is it just a time limitation for the devs, or a design issue? If a design issue, the design is deep-sixing effective spam blocking on the part of the users. It's inadequate, (or antiquated).

Do you happen to know what the proper procedure is for prioritizing this RFE? Piles of $$$$$? LOL!

I might have to crack open the 20-year-unused c-coding part of my brain(ouch!) and take a look at the source.

Thanks for responding.
creator: friendlygrey60

content:
I tend to think that most requests for changes that come from outside the TB developer group have little chance of success.

I don't pay much attention to TB's junk controls and have never used them, finding that the limited amount of spam I receive is well-managed by the mail providers. A judicious deployment of one's accounts is probably the best means of limiting junk mail.
creator: sfhowes

content: I agree with sfhowes about spam/junk. Blocking/filtering at the server and prevention are best. I would be depressed if much spam/junk reached Thunderbird.
creator: mozilla98

content:
I have several email addresses from various vendors. Thunderbird does an amazing job at handling all of them.

Trying to manage the various spam filtering provided by the 3-4 different vendors would be an annoyance.

Controlling it in one, central location allows a reduction in effort.
creator: friendlygrey60

content:
friendlygrey60 said
I have several email addresses from various vendors. Thunderbird does an amazing job at handling all of them. Trying to manage the various spam filtering provided by the 3-4 different vendors would be an annoyance. Controlling it in one, central location allows a reduction in effort.

Makes sense, especially if you do not use web mail or other e-mail clients.
creator: mozilla98

content:
-hate- web mail/clients. WHY would I subject myself to having to use 20 billion different web UI's, all different?


I never log into the web UI's except for those unfriendly providers that fail to fully delete old mail when I archive&purge the accounts every 3-4 months. That was using POP for some of them, and since converting to a pure IMAP environment, that issue has pretty much evaporated.


Using thunderbird as the central contact point and UI for all of my mail is bee-youtiful!

This lack of a functioning multimode Body filter is a minor issue compared to the simplicity that TB provides in compensation.

If the devs were listening to me, about the only other thing I can think of that I'd ask for (other than a more functional Body filter) would be a -global- message filter that applies to all of my several email addresses.(IE, even more simplification). That was easy enough to correct for with a simple script that replicates the msgFilterRules.dat out to all accounts from a template/source account, but it would be cleaner if TB could to it.

Other than those two minor issues, life is beautiful with TB.
creator: friendlygrey60

content:
Regarding global filters: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1535654

I seldom access webmail, but make use of the generally effective providers' spam filtering, and monitor Spam/Junk IMAP folders in TB.

N'en ayant pas reçu récemment, je ne peux en faire de copie d'écran. Jusqu à présent, je répondais OUI, mais m'étant aperçu que depuis quelques mois je recevais quelques Emails frauduleux auxquels je n'ai bien sûr pas répondu, j'ai pensé qu'il fallait par sécurité plutôt répondre NON, ce que d'après votre dernière réponse je n'aurais pas dû faire. Résultat, je reçois maintenant beaucoup moins d'Emails qu'auparavant ce que je trouve anormal. J'espère que vous pourrez m'aider à retrouver un fonctionnement plus normal de Thunderbird. Cordialement.

JP Grandsire

content:
Generally the option of the strikethrough means it's not hidden as this is the prefered option. It needs to still be visible, but shows as a deleted email. This is usually used if the person does not want to move it to Trash folder where they would only see it if they selected the Trash folder. Some servers auto empty Trash folders, so anyone using an Imap account may like to manually move them at a later date.

I find it's not really a good option for me as I use a gmail imap account. So a strikethrough email will get removed as soon as folders synchronises with server. Basically, gmail interprets this as remove the label. I cannot see email as it's no longer in folder. The email is now in the 'All Mail' folder (I do not subscribe to see it), so I would have to logon to webmail, locate it in 'All Mail' and reapply a label.

An idea: You could mark it as ignored, then it would get hidden unless you selected to 'View' > Threads' > 'Ignored Threads'

Info here: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/ignore-threads

creator: arvyrogerio

content:
I've solved it. Well, almost.

After several attempts, I resolved it with the following:

- I cleaned all traces of Thunderbird. - I installed version 143. - I created a new profile. - I imported the email settings from the copy I made of the original profile's directory contents. - I had to enter the passwords for all the accounts. - I imported the email contents, which were stored in a local folder.

It wasn't ideal, but it partially worked.

content:
Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: You could create a filter that sets all messages to unread. Set that filter to run first.
creator: davidsk

content: I can't see how that would work since the filters aren't picking up the incoming "reads" in the first place. If it's "read" the filter process is ignored. What is required is a way of setting "unread" BEFORE the filters come into it.

content:
In Thunderbird per Android vai in Menu > Impostazioni (l'icona dell'ingranaggio) > NOME_ACCOUNT > Recupero dei messaggi

Qui trovi la voce Frequenza sincronizzazione cartella Tocca questa voce e scegli un intervallo più breve, ad esempio 15 min.

Per la ricezione in tempo reale bisogna invece intervenire sulla configurazione di Android. In particolare devi assicurarti che Thunderbird non sia soggetto alle limitazioni del risparmio energetico di Android. Come farlo però dipende dal singolo modello di smartphone.

content:
Hi,

The people who answer questions here, for the most part, are other users volunteering their time (like me), not Mozilla employees or developers. If you want to leave feedback for developers, you can go to the Firefox Help menu and select Share ideas and feedback…. Alternatively, you can use this link. Your feedback gets collected by a team of people who read it and gather data about the most common issues.

You can also file a bug report or feature request. See File a bug report or feature request for Mozilla products for details.
creator: @shah_E_kharabar

content: Or would you like help getting your filters to work? If so, post screenshots of rules.
creator: mozilla98

content:
I think the search you described is Global Search ("Edit" > "Find" > "Global Search", or Ctrl + K), and the behavior you described is explained in the "Search terms" section in the following link: Global Search https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/global-search

If you do not want this behavior, you can use the following two search methods:

1. "Edit" > "Find" > "Search Messages" (Ctrl + Shift + F)

Reference: Using Saved Searches https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/using-saved-searches

Although the above link talks about Saved Search rather than Search Messages, I think the concept applies to Search Messages to some extent.

2. Quick Filter (Ctrl + Shift + K)

Reference: Quick Filter Toolbar https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/quick-filter-toolbar
creator: Yu5tiqX9og

creator: mozilla98

content:
This can be done with userChrome.css (see picture): 

#MsgHeadersToolbar {margin-left: -70px !important;}


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the number as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video: How to create a css file (Firefox or TB)
creator: sfhowes

content: Go View and ToolBars and then check Status Bar
creator: MichelT

content:
That worked Michael T but ironically, the Status Bar check box was already checked (and had been during my own troubleshooting). So .... I unchecked it .... then shut down Thunderbird and restarted it.

Ironically, when I restarted T-Bird, the Status Bar had been re-enabled (even though I had taken no action to re-check the box that enables it). And .... drum roll .... the status bar was back, and showed progress of email fetches.

So ... problem solved, but I still don't understand why I originally had no status bar, even though View/Toolbars/Status bar was checked. My instincts tell me some kind of funny business happened when I updated T-Bird to version 143.0 and it looked for a 'Status Bar' token in my computer account Applications Support area.

Bottom line: it works now and I credit you Michael T for suggesting I fool around with View/Toolbars/Status Bar setting.
creator: dncollins

content: Please clarify what your issue is with filters.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thunderbird is what is called an e-mail client. It sends and receives e-mail through accounts at e-mail servers (Yahoo, Google, Microsoft, Apple, et al.), which is much more than helping people transfer messages from Yahoo to gmail.

Thunderbird does not have its own accounts and server, but they are in development and will someday be available for a fee.
